data.title: Famous Croatians in History
data.meta_description: List of the most famous Croatians in history, with famous, important and notable Croatians hand-picked by our team of editors and ranked by popularity.
data.text:
Famous Croatians

Home

Famous People

Nationality

Croatian

1. Franjo Tuđman

2. Goran Ivanišević

3. Ante Pavelić

4. Luka Modrić

5. Iva Majoli

List of Croatian People

Marko Marulic/Marulus/Splichanin/Pechinich, Croatian poet, born in Split, Croatia (d. 1524)

Džore Držić, Croatian poet and playwright who is considered one of the fathers of Croatian literature, born in Dubrovnik, Croatia (d. 1501)

Matthias Flacius, Croatian Lutheran Protestant reformer, born in Labin, Venetian Republic (d. 1575)

Bartol Kašić, Croatian writer and linguist, born in Pag, Croatia (d. 1650)

Ivan Lukačić, Croatian composer, born in Šibenik, Croatia (d. 1648)

Stjepan Gradić, Croatian philosopher and scientist (d. 1683)

Ferdinand Konščak, Croatian explorer and Jesuit missionary, born in Varaždin, Kingdom of Croatia (d. 1759)

Roger Boscovich [Ruđer Bošković], Croatian-Italian astronomer. physicist, poet, and priest, born in Ragusa (Dubrovnik), Republic of Ragusa (now Croatia) (d. 1787)

Ignacije Szentmartony, Croatian Jesuit missionary and geographer, born in Kottori, Kingdom of Hungary (d. 1793)

Matija A Reljkovic, Habsburg military officer & Croatian writer (Satir iliti divji covic), born in Davor, Croatia (d. 1798)

Luca Sorkočević, Croatian nobleman and composer (composed 1st Croatian symphony), born in Dubrovnik, Republic of Rugosa (now Croatia) (d. 1789)

Ljudwit Gaj, Croatian writer and poet of the Illyrian movement (Pjesma iz Zagorja), born in Krapina, Kingdom of Croatia (d. 1872)

Stanko Vraz [Jakob Frass], Slovenian-Croatian poet (illyrism), born in Cerovec in Lower Styria, Austrian Empire (d. 1851)

Vatroslav Lisinski [Ignatius Fuchs], Croatian composer (Love and Malice), born in Zagreb, Kingdom of Croatia, Austrian Empire (d. 1854)

Josip Runjanin, Croatian Serb composer (Croatian National Anthem) and soldier, born in Vinkovci (d. 1878)

Franjo Rački, Croatian historian and politician, born in Fužine, Austrian Empire (d. 1894)

Ivan Zajc, Croatian composer and conductor, born in Rijeka, Croatia (d. 1914)

Ema Puksec, Croatian singer, born in Ogulin, Croatia (d. 1889)

Franjo Ksaver Kuhač, Croatian composer who collected and published 1,600 folk songs, born in Osijek, Croatia (d. 1911)

Vatroslav Jagić, Croatian scholar of Slavic studies, born in Varaždin, Austrian Empire (d. 1923)

August Senoa, Croatian writer (Zlatarevo zlato), born in Zagreb, Croatia (d. 1881)

Anthony Francis Lucas, Croatian-American oil exploration pioneer, born in Split, Austria-Hungary (d. 1921)

Dragutin Gorjanovic-Kramberger, Croatian paleontologist (discovery and descriptions of the Neandertal remains from the Huŝnjakova rock shelter at Krapina in northwestern Croatia), born in Zagreb, Croatia (d. 1936)

Svetozar Boroević, Austro-Hungarian field marshal, born in Umetić, Croatian Military Frontier, Austrian Empire (d. 1920)

Andrija Mohorovicic, Croatian meteorologist & seismologist (Moho discontinuity), born in Opatija, Croatia (d. 1936)

Juan Vucetich, Croatian-born Argentine anthropologist who pioneered fingerprint identification, born in Hvar, Kingdom of Dalmatia (d. 1925)

Vjenceslav Novak, Croatian Realist writer (Pavao Šegota), born in Senj, Croatia (d. 1905)

Artur Gavazzi, Croatian geographer, born in Split, Austria-Hungary (d. 1944)

Franjo Krežma, Croatian violinist, born in Osijek, Croatia (d. 1881)

Dragutin Lerman, Croatian explorer, born in Požega, Croatia (d. 1918)

Julije Kempf, Croatian historian and writer, born in Požega, Croatia (d. 1934)

Ante Trumbić, Croatian politician (23rd Mayor of Split), born in Split, Dalmatia, Austria-Hungary (d. 1938)

Mirko Seljan, Croatian explorer, born in Karlovac, Croatia (d. 1913)

Stjepan Radic, Croatian politician (founder of Croatian People's Peasant Party), born in Desno Trebarjevo, Austria-Hungary (d. 1928)

Didak Buntić, Croatian monk and scholar, born in Paoča, Bosnia and Herzegovina (d. 1922)

Blagoje Bersa, Croatian composer, born in Dubrovnik, Croatia (d. 1934)

Ivana Brlić-Mažuranić, Croatian writer (The Brave Adventures of Lapitch), born in Ogulin, Croatian Military Frontier, Austria-Hungary (d. 1938)

Stjepan Seljan, Croatian explorer (Ethiopia, South America), born in Karlovac, Croatia (d. 1936)

Slava Raskaj, Croatian painter (d. 1906)

Milan Šufflay, Croatian historian and politician, born in Lepoglava, Croatia (d. 1931)

Ivan Meštrović, Croatian sculptor and architect, born in Vrpolje, Croatia (d. 1962)

(Theodora) "Dora" Pejačević, Croatian countess and composer (Symphony in F-sharp minor, Op. 41), born in Budapest, Kingdom of Hungary (d. 1923)

Leopold Ružička, Croatian-Swiss chemist (Nobel 1939), born in Vukovar, Croatia (d. 1976)

Paula von Preradović, Croatian-Austrian poet and writer, born in Vienna, Austria (d. 1951)

Krsto Odak, Croatian composer, born in Siverić (d. 1965)

Andrija Štampar, Croatian physician (d. 1958)

Ante Pavelić, Croatian leader of Nazi Germany puppet Independent State of Croatia, born in Bradina, Austria-Hungary (d. 1959)

Božidar Širola, Croatian composer, born in Žakanje, Croatia (d. 1956)

Vinko Zganec, Croatian ethnomusicologist, born in Vratišinec, Kingdom of Croatia-Slavonia (d. 1976)

Tin Ujević, Croatian poet (Žedan kamen na studencu), born in Vrgorac, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1955)

Miroslav Krleža, Croatian poet, novelist and playwright (Ballads of Petrica Kerempuh), born in Zagreb, Croatia-Slavonia, Austria-Hungary (d. 1981)

Zlatko Baloković, Croatian-American concert violinist, born in Zagreb, Kingdom of Croatia-Slavonia, Austria-Hungary (d. 1955)

Jakov Gotovac, Croatian conductor and composer (Ero the Joker), born in Split, Austria-Hungary (now Croatia) (d. 1982)

Jakov Gotovac, Croatian composer, born in Split, Austria-Hungary (d. 1982)

Josip Slavenski, Croatian composer and pedagogue, born in Čakovec, Croatia-Slavonia, Austria-Hungary (d. 1955)

Lovro von Matačić, Croatian conductor and composer (Bruckner Medal), born in Sušak, Croatia (d. 1985)

Andrija Artuković, Croatian war criminal (d. 1988)

Andrija Maurovic, Croatian illustrator (The Tomb in the Rainforest), born in Muo, Austria-Hungary (d. 1981)

Božidar Kunc, Croatian concert pianist and composer, born in Zagreb, Croatia (d. 1964)

Danilo Blanuša, Croatian mathematician, born in Osijek, Austria-Hungary (d. 1987)

Vjekoslav Kaleb, Croatian writer (Splendor of the Fabric), born in Tisno, Croatia (d. 1996)

Boris Papandopulo, Croatian composer, born in Bad Honnef, Germany (d. 1991)

Zinka Milanov (née Kunc), Croatian soprano (Ljubljana Opera, 1927-34; NY Metropolitan Opera, 1937-66), born in Zagreb, Croatia (d. 1989)

William Feller, Croatian-American mathematician known for probability theory, born in Zagreb, Austria-Hungary (d. 1970)

Vladimir Prelog, Croatian-Swiss organic chemist (Nobel 1975), born in Sarajevo, Austria-Hungary (d. 1998)

Ivan Brkanović, Croatian composer (Triptych - Funeral Folk Rite), born in Škaljari, Montenegro (d. 1987)

Krešimir Fribec, Croatian composer, born in Daruvar, Croatia (d. 1996)

Marko Rothmuller, Croatian composer, born in Slavonski Brod, Croatia (d. 1993)

Petar Šegedin, Croatian novelist (Holy Devil), born in Žrnovo, island of Korčula (d. 1998)

Bruno Bjelinski [Weiss], Croatian composer, born in Trieste, Austria-Hungary (d. 1992)

Nikola Hercigonja, Croatian composer, born in Vinkovci, Kingdom of Croatia and Slavonia (d. 2000)

Ico Hitrec, Croatian footballer, born in Zagreb, Austria-Hungary (d. 1946)

Tibor Sekelj, Croatian explorer (d. 1988)

Vladimir Žerjavić, Croatian economist and UN statistician, born in Križ, Moslavania, Croatia (d. 2001)

Natko Devčić, Croatian composer, born in Glina, Kingdom of Croatia-Slavonia, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1997)

Stjepan Sulek, Croatian violinist and composer (Coriolan), born in Zagreb, Croatia (d. 1986)

Albe Vidaković, Croatian composer, born in Subotica, Serbia (d. 1964)

Ivan Generalić, Croatian painter, born in Hlebine, Croatia (d. 1992)

Rudolf Brucci [Bruči], Italian-Croatian composer (Gilgamesh; Lesta), and educator, born in Zagreb, Austrian-Hungarian Empire (d. 2002)

Branimir Sakač, Croatian composer (Matrix Symphony), born in Zagreb (d. 1979)

Emil Cossetto, Croatian composer, born in Trieste, Austria-Hungary (d. 2006)

Edo Murtić, Croatian painter, born in Velika Pisanica, Bjelovar, Croatia (d. 2005)

Franjo Tuđman, Croatian politician and President of Croatia (1990-1999), born in Veliko Trgovišće, Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes (d. 1999)

Milko Kelemen, Croatian composer (Archetypon), born in Slatina, Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes (d. 2018)

Victor Grinich, Croatian-American businessman (d. 2000)

Lovro Zupanovic, Croatian composer, born in Šibenik, Croatia (d. 2004)

Great Antonio [Antonio Barichievich], Croatian-Canadian strongman and eccentric, born in Zagreb, Yugoslavia (d. 2003)

Zlatko Pibernik, Croatian composer and music teacher, born in Zagreb, Croatia (d. 2010)

Bernard Vukas, Croatian soccer forward (59 caps, Yugoslavia; Hajduk Split; Olympic silver 1948, 52), born in Zagreb, Croatia (d. 1983)

Duje Bonačić, Croatian rower (Olympic gold coxless four 1952), born in Split, Croatia (d. 2020)

Stanko Horvat, Croatian composer, born in Zagreb, Croatia (d. 2006)

Ruben Radica, Croatian classical and electronic music composer (Towards A), and educator, born in Split, Yugoslavia (d. 2021)

Branko Lustig, Croatian film producer (Schindler's List; Gladiator), born in Osijek, Kingdom of Yugoslavia (now Croatia) (d. 2019)

Otto Barić, Croatian soccer manager (Croatia, Austria, Wacker Innsbruck, SK Rapid, SV Salzburg), born in Eisenkappel, Austria (d. 2020)

Pavle Despalj, Croatian composer and conductor (Zagreb; Miami; Tokyo), born in Blato, Korčula (d. 2021)

Bosko Petrovic, Croatian jazz musician, founder of the Zagreb Jazz Quartet, born in Bjelovar (d. 2011)

Ivo Trumbić, Croatian water polo player (Olympic gold 1968 Yugoslavia) and coach (Olympic bronze Netherlands 1976), born in Split, Croatia (d. 2021)

Vinko "Vice" Vukov, Croatian singer (Eurovision Song Contest 1963 & 1965), born in Šibenik, Kingdom of Yugoslavia (d. 2008)

Dubravko Detoni, Croatian composer, born in Križevci, Croatia

Mirko Novosel, Croatian Basketball HOF coach (EuroLeague C'ship 1985, 1986; European Coach of the Year 1985 Cibona Zagreb; 7 × Yugoslav Cup), born in Zagreb, Croatia (d. 2023)

Arsen Dedić, Croatian singer-songwriter and poet, born in Šibenik, Kingdom of Yugoslavia (d. 2015)

Tereza Kesovija, Croatian popular music singer, born in Dubrovnik, Kingdom of Yugoslavia (now Croatia)

Boris Dvornik, Croatian actor, born in Split, Kingdom of Yugoslavia (d. 2008)

Boro Jovanović, Croatian tennis player (Wimbledon doubles 1962 runner-up [Nikola Pilić]), born in Zagreb, Croatia (d. 2023)

Stjepan Lamza, Croatian soccer midfielder (7 caps Yugoslavia; GNK Dinamo Zagreb), born in Sisak, Croatia (d. 2022)

Slaven Zambata, Croatian soccer forward (31 caps Yugoslavia; Dinamo Zagreb), born in Sinj, Croatia (d. 2020)

Mišo Kovač, Croatian country-pop-folk singer (Mojoj vjernoj publici), born in Sebenico, Governorate of Dalmatia, Kingdom of Italy

Petar Nadoveza, Croatian soccer striker (1 cap; Yugoslavia; Hajduk Split 217 games) and manager (Hajduk Split 1982-84, 1988-89, 2000, 2004), born in Šibenik, Croatia (d. 2023)

Đorđe Novković, Croatian pop singer-songwriter (Pro Arte), and television personality (Hrvatski Idol), born in Vladimirci, German-occupied Serbia (d. 2007)

Dunja Vejzović, Croatian soprano, born in Zagreb, Croatia

Petar Skansi, Croatian basketball center (Olympic silver Yugoslavia 1968; Jugoplastika) and coach (Yugoslavia, Croatia, Jugoplastika, Benetton Treviso), born in Sumartin, Croatia (d. 2022)

Krasnodar Rora, Croatian soccer midfielder (5 caps Yugoslavia; Dinamo Zagreb, Standard Liège) and manager (Šibenik), born in Vis, Croatia (d. 2020)

Rade Šerbedžija, Croatian actor (Taken 2), born in Bunić, Croatia

Damir Šolman, Croatian basketball small forward (World Cup gold 1970, silver 1974 Yugoslavia; Olympic silver 1968, 76; FIBA European Selection 1974; Mladost Zagreb, Jugoplastika), born in Zagreb, Croatia (d. 2023)

Krešimir Ćosić, Croatian basketball player, born in Zagreb, PR Croatia, FPR Yugoslavia (d. 1995)

Dado Topić, Croatian musician (Time; Dragonfly), born in Nova Gradiška, Croatia

Mario Boljat, Croatian soccer defender-midfielder (5 caps; Hajduk Split, Schalke 04), born in Split, Croatia (d. 2024)

Branimir "Johnny" Štulić, Croatian rock singer (Azra), born in Skopje, Yugoslavia

Branko Cikatić, Croatian kickboxer (first K-1 World Grand Prix Heavyweight C'ship 1993), born in Split, Croatia (d. 2020)

Mira Furlan, Croatian actress (Babylon 5), born in Zagreb, Croatia

Željka Antunović, Croatian politician, 1st female Minister of Defence, born in Virovitica, Yugoslavia

Ante Gotovina, Croatian army general accused of war crimes, born in Tkon, Croatia

Zlatko Kranjčar, Croatian soccer striker (2 caps; Dinamo Zagreb, Rapid Wien) and manager (Croatia, Montenegro, Dinamo Zagreb), born in Zagreb, Croatia (d. 2021)

Zeljko Ivanek, Slovenian-Croatian-American actor (Damages), born in Lujubljana, Yugoslavia

Hrvoje Horvatic, Croatian filmmaker (Hand on the Shoulder), born in Rijeka, Yugoslavia (d. 1997)

Ivo Pogorelić, Croatian pianist (1978 Casagrande winner), born in Belgrade, Yugoslavia

Mario Igrec, Croatian jazz guitarist, composer and music professor (Cubismo), born in Zagreb, Croatia

Zorica Kondža, Croatian pop singer (Stijene), born in Split, Yugoslavia

Tihomir Blaškić, Croatian war criminal, born in Kiseljak, Bosnia and Herzegovina

Dobroslav Paraga, Croatian politician and editor, born in Zagreb, FPR Yugoslavia

Doris Dragović, Croatian pop singer ("Marija Magdalena"), born in Split, Yugoslavia

Zlatko Saračević, Croatian handball player (145 caps Yugoslavia, 75 Croatia; Olympic gold 1996 Croatia), born in Banja Luka, Bosnia & Herzegovina (d. 2021)

Sanja Doležal, Croatian pop singer (Novi fosili), and television personality, born in Zagreb, SFR Yugoslavia (now Croatia)

Elvis Stanić, Croatian contemporary jazz fusion guitarist, born in Rijeka, Yugoslavia

Stojko Vrankovic, Croatian NBA center (LA Clippers), born in Drniš, Croatia

Goran Prpić, Croatian tennis player (Hopman Cup Yugoslavia 1991 [Monica Seles], born in Zagreb, Croatia

Miljenko "Dino" Dvornik, Croatian singer known as "the Croatian King of Funk", born in Split, SR Croatia, SFR Yugoslavia (d. 2008)

Saša Britvić, Croatian conductor (Croatian Baroque Ensemble, 1999-2015), and pedagogue, born in Zagreb, Yugoslavia (now Croatia) (d. 2015)

Zoran Milanović, Croatian politician (President of Croatia 2020-), born in Zagreb, Yugoslavia

Dino Radja, Croatian basketball player (Boston Celtics), born in Split, Croatia

Ante Miše, Croatian soccer player (Hajduk Split/Vitesse), born in Vukovar, SR Croatia, SFR Yugoslavia

Davor Šuker, Croatian soccer striker (68 caps; Sevilla; President Croatian FF), born in Osijek, Croatia

Toni Kukoč, Croatian basketball forward (NBA C'ship 1996, 97, 98 Chicago Bulls; NBA Sixth Man of the Year 1996; 5 × Euroscar Player of the Year), born in Split, Croatia

Zvonimir Boban, Croatian football player and Deputy Secretary General of FIFA, born in Imotski, Croatia

Vlado Šola, Croatian handball goalkeeper

Robert Prosinečki, Croatian footballer, born in Villingen-Schwenningen, Germany

Vanna [Ivana Ranilović-Vrdoljak], Croatian pop singer, born in Koprivnica, Croatia, Yugoslavia

Danijela [Martinović], Croatian pop singer (Magazin, 1991-96; solo - "Brodolom" ("Shipwreck")), born in Split, SR Croatia, Yugoslavia

Goran Ivanišević, Croatian tennis player (Wimbledon 2001), born in Split, Croatia

Severina [Vuckovic], Croatian pop singer and actress (Moja Stikla), born in Split, SFR Yugoslavia

Goran Višnjić, Croatian actor, born in Šibenik, Croatia

Lucija Šerbedžija, Croatian actress

Robert Kovač, Croatian footballer

Ivana Miličević, Croatian-American actress (Banshee), born in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina

Dado Pršo, Croatian footballer, born in Zadar, SFR Yugoslavia

Maksim Mrvica, Croatian pianist, born in Šibenik, Croatia

Iva Majoli, Croatian tennis player (1996 Pan Pacific), born in Zagreb, Croatia

Josip Šimunić, Croatian footballer, born in Canberra, Australia

Vesna Pisarović, Croatian singer, born in Brčko, Bosnia-Herzegovina

Luka Udjbinac, Croatian jazz musician, born in Zagreb, Croatia

Martina Filjak, Croatian concert pianist, born in Zagreb, Croatia

Stipe Pletikosa, Croatian footballer, born in Split, Croatia

Ivo Karlović, Croatian tennis player, born in Zagreb, Croatia

Ivan Ljubičić, Croatian tennis player

Ivano Balić, Croatian handballer (198 caps; Olympic gold 2004; World C'ship gold 2003), born in Split, Croatia

Tomo Miličević, Croatian-American rock guitarist (Thirty Seconds to Mars, 2003-18 - "The Kill", "Closer to the Edge"), and record producer, born in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia

Kristina Krepela, Croatian actress, born in Zagreb, Croatia

Ivan Klasnić, Croatian soccer striker (41 caps; FC St. Pauli, Werder Bremen, Nantes, Bolton Wanderers), born in Hamburg, Germany

Jerko Leko, Croatian footballer, born in Zagreb, Croatia

Mario Stojić, Croatian basketball player

Ivica Banović, Croatian footballer, born in Zagreb, Croatia

Ana Vidovic, Croatian classical guitarist, born in Karlovac, Croatia

Danijel Pranjić, Croatian soccer wingback (58 caps; SC Heerenveen), born in Našice, Croatia

Janica Kostelić, Croatian skier, born in Zagreb, Croatia

Darijo Srna, Croatian soccer defender (134 caps; Shakhtar Donetsk 339 games), born in Metković, Croatia

Blanka Vlašić, Croatian high jumper, born in Split, Croatia

Mario Ančić, Croatian tennis player (world #7 2006; Davis Cup 2005), born in Split, Croatia

Niko Kranjčar, Croatian soccer midfielder (81 caps; Dinamo Zagreb, Hajduk Split, Portsmouth, Tottenham Hotspur, QPR), born in Zagreb, Croatia

Ivan Dodig, Croatian tennis player (6 x Grand Slam doubles titles; Davis Cup 2018), born in Međugorje, Bosnia and Herzegovina

Luka Modrić, Croatian footballer (Real Madrid C.F.) and captain of Croatia, born in Zadar, Croatia, Yugoslavia

Bruno Vlahek, Croatian concert pianist and contemporary classical composer, born in Zagreb, Croatia

Stjepan Hauser, Croatian cellist (2Cellos), born in Pula, Croatia

Luka Šulić, Slovenian-Croatian cellist (2Cellos), born in Maribor, Slovenia

Ivan Rakitić, Croatian football player (FC Barcelona, Croatian national team), born in Möhlin, Switzerland

Marin Čilić, Croatian tennis player (US Open 2014), born in Medjugorje, Bosnia & Herzegovina

Ivan Perišić, Croatian football player (Inter Milan), born in Split, Yugoslavia

Dejan Lovren, Croatian footballer (Liverpool), born in Zenica, Yugoslavia

Dino Jelusić, Croatian singer, born in Požega, Croatia

Josko Gvardiol, Croatian football player (Manchester City), born in Zagreb, Croatia
